identified-content.classifier: Health Maintenance Organizations and Managed Care

abstract.p: Letter by Thomas Ockers of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center on Feb 8 article that hospitals, pharmacists and doctors on Long Island, NY, are dismayed over inability to collect tens of millions of dollars in overdue bills from health maintenance organizations (S)

block.p: The article ''Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals'' in the Feb. 8, section incorrectly reported vital information concerning Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center.

Brookhaven, a 321-bed acute-care medical center has 1,900 employees, not 900 as reported. Secondly, the reported freeze in rates was in the Medicare rate, not the Medicaid rate. The medical center receives 57 percent of its revenue from Medicare patients, not Medicaid patients. This freeze, a result of the Federal Balanced Budget Act, had a $2.3 million negative impact on our budget for 1998.
The article ''Slow H.M.O. Bill Payments Strain Hospitals'' in the Feb. 8, section incorrectly reported vital information concerning Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center.

Brookhaven, a 321-bed acute-care medical center has 1,900 employees, not 900 as reported. Secondly, the reported freeze in rates was in the Medicare rate, not the Medicaid rate. The medical center receives 57 percent of its revenue from Medicare patients, not Medicaid patients. This freeze, a result of the Federal Balanced Budget Act, had a $2.3 million negative impact on our budget for 1998.

We have taken a number of steps to balance our budget without reducing programs or affecting the quality of patient care. Like other leading medical centers across the country, we are redesigning the delivery of care to a ''patient centered'' model, decentralizing departments and expaning employee skills. We feel that through these efforts our medical center will be a stronger and more responsive health care provider.
THOMAS OCKERS Brookaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center
